case_name: Durga Prasad & Roshan Lal v. Official Liquidator, Banaras Bank Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 569 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURTSDICTION Civil Appeal No. 569 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 9, 1958 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 214 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 9, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 214 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered on December 21, 1962 by SHAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. December 21. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-

facts.text: Banaras Bank Ltd was directed to be wound up by order of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Banaras Bank Ltd-hereinafter called the Bank was directed to be wound up by order of the Allahabad High Court.

facts.text: A committee of inspection was appointed under s. 178-A of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 to act with the Official Liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: A companymittee of inspection was appointed under s. 178-A of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 to act with the Official Liquidator,

facts.text: Durga Prasad, the first appellant, was a member of the committee of inspection.

anchor.surface_text: and one of the members of the Committee was Durga Prasad the first appellant in this appeal.

facts.text: Official Liquidator advertised for sale two houses which formed part of the assets of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The Official Liquidator advertised for sale two houses which formed part of the assets of the Bank.

facts.text: Roshan Lal, the second appellant, made an offer to purchase the two houses for Rs. 18,000.

anchor.surface_text: Roshan Lal the second appellant made an offer to purchase the two houses for Rs. 18,000/- .

facts.text: Offer of Roshan Lal was accepted by the Official Liquidator and sanctioned by the Court.

anchor.surface_text: This offer was accepted by the Official Liquidator and with the sanction of the Court the two houses were sold

facts.text: Two houses sold to Roshan Lal on August 2, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: to Roshan Lal on August 2, 1941. Roshan Lal thereafter transferred the houses to Durga Prasad

facts.text: Roshan Lal transferred the houses to Durga Prasad reciting in the deed that Durga Prasad was the real owner and the sale was benami.

anchor.surface_text: Roshan Lal thereafter transferred the houses to Durga Prasad reciting in the deed that the latter was the real owner of the houses and that the sale deed from the Official Liquidator was obtained by him benami for Durga Prasad.

facts.text: Official Liquidator moved the Allahabad High Court to declare the sale null and void and direct Durga Prasad to surrender and retransfer the houses to the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: On companying to learn about this companyveyance, the Official Liquidator moved the High Court of Allahabad for an order that the sale be declared null and void and that Durga Prasad be called upon to surrender the two houses and to retransfer the same to the Bank.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held that the sale deed was obtained by Durga Prasad who was the real purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the sale deed was obtained by Durga Prasad who was the real purchaser, that he had suppressed his interest in the purchase,

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held that Durga Prasad suppressed his interest in the purchase.

anchor.surface_text: that the sale deed was obtained by Durga Prasad who was the real purchaser, that he had suppressed his interest in the purchase,

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held that Durga Prasad, as member of committee of inspection, occupied position of trustee qua the Bank and was precluded from buying Bank property.

anchor.surface_text: and that being a member of the companymittee for inspection, qua the Bank he occupied the position of a trustee and was on that account precluded from. buying the property of the Bank.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court directed Durga Prasad to convey the houses to the Official Liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly directed Durga Prasad to companyey the houses to the Official Liquidator of the Bank.

facts.text: High Court order confirmed in appeal under cl. 10 of Letters Patent by Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: This order was companyfirmed in appeal tinder cl. 10 of the Letters Patent by a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: High Court certified the case under Art. 133(1) of the Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, certified the case under Art. 33  1  of the Constitution for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: It is not in dispute that the High Court judgment involves a claim respecting property of value not less than Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed It is number in dispute that the judgment of this Court involves directly or indirectly a claim respecting property of a value of number less than Rs. 20,006/-

facts.text: At hearing before Supreme Court, counsel for Official Liquidator submitted that the appeal is incompetent as no substantial question of law certified.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before this Court companynsel for the Official Liquidator submitted that the appeal is incompetent, for the High Court had numberjurisdiction to grant the certificate under Art. 133  1   a  of the Constitution without certifying that the appeal involved some substantial question of law.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the contention of incompetence succeeds and appeal cannot be entertained.

anchor.surface_text: In our view this companytention must succeed. ... The appeal cannot accordingly be entertained.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant requested special leave to appeal under Art. 136, but Supreme Court denied.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant requested that in any event special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution be granted. But we are of the view, having regard to all thecircumstances, that this is number a fit case for granting leave to appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appealis therefore dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction to grant the certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) of the Constitution without certifying that the appeal involved some substantial question of law

anchor.surface_text: the High Court had numberjurisdiction to grant the certificate under Art. 133  1   a  of the Constitution without certifying that the appeal involved some substantial question of law.

arguments.claim: Applicants are entitled as of right to a certificate under Article 133(1) of the Constitution without an additional certificate that the case gives rise to a substantial question of law because the judgment involves a claim respecting property of value not less than Rs. 20,000 and in view of Deoki Nandan precedent

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed It is number in dispute that the judgment of this Court involves directly or indirectly a claim respecting property of a value of number less than Rs. 20,006/- and, in view of the decision of this Court in Shri Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh  1 , the applicants are entitled as of right to a certificate under Article 133  1  of the Constitution without an additional certificate that the case gives rise to a substantial question of law.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: appeal to this Court. The High Court observed It is number in dispute that the judgment of this Court involves directly or indirectly a claim respect

arguments.court_reasoning: Deoki Nandan concerned appeal from dismissal of writ petition under Art. 226 by single judge, affirmed by bench; different from Letters Patent appeal confirming single judge order in winding up proceeding

arguments.claim: The appeal is incompetent because the High Court had no jurisdiction to grant the certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) without certifying that the appeal involved some substantial question of law

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before this Court companynsel for the Official Liquidator submitted that the appeal is incompetent, for the High Court had numberjurisdiction to grant the certificate under Art. 133  1   a  of the Constitution without certifying that the appeal involved some substantial question of law.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er, certified the case under Art. 33  1  of the Constitution for

arguments.court_reasoning: Contention succeeds as confirmed by analysis of precedents requiring substantial question of law certification for such appeals

arguments.claim: In Deoki Nandan, substantial question of law not required only for appeals from orders dismissing writ petitions under Art. 226; the expression 'court immediately below' differs from 'court subordinate'

anchor.surface_text: In Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh the Allahabad High Court held. The words the Court immediately below within the meaning of cl.  1  of Art. 133 of the Constitution must be a companyrt other than the High Court. A single judge of a High Court is number a companyrt subordinate to the High Court.

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Toolsey Persaud held that appeal under S. 696 CPC 1882 (similar to Art. 133(1)) from Letters Patent appeal from single judge original proceeding requires substantial question of law

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against an order of an appellate Bench of the High Court dismissing an appeal from an order of a single judge of the Court on its original side rejecting a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution lies as a matter of right under Art. 133  1  of the Constitution, if the claim is in respect of property of a value in excess of Rs. 20,000/- and it is number

arguments.claim: Calcutta High Court in Probhawati Kunwar held that appeal to Privy Council from High Court confirming single judge original proceeding cannot be certified without substantial question of law

anchor.surface_text: necessary that the case should give rise to a substantial question of law. But the expression companyrt immediately below in Art. 133  1  has number the same companynotation as the expression companyrt subordinate to the High Court. In Toolsey Persaud Bhuckt v. Benayek Misser  1 , the Privy Council appears to have expressed the view that a single judge of a High Court trying an original proceeding was a companyrt immediately below the High Court hearing an appeal under the Letters Patent from his judgment and therefore an appeal under S. 696 of the Code of Civil Procedure Act XIV of 1882  of which the terms were in substance identical with the terms of Art. 133  1

arguments.claim: In Ladli Prasad, Supreme Court held single judge hearing second appeal under S.100 CPC is court immediately below Division Bench under Letters Patent for Art.133(1)(a); concession properly made for original jurisdiction single judge

anchor.surface_text: In a recent case Ladli Prasad Jaisuul v. The Karnal Distillery Company Ltd.  3 , this Court held that a single Judge hearing a second appeal under S. 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 is for purposes of Art. 133  1  the Court immediately below a Division Bench of the High Court hearing an appeal against his judgment under the Letters Patent.

arguments.claim: Special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution should be granted

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant requested that in any event special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution be granted. But we are of the view, having regard to all thecircumstances, that this is number a fit case for granting leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On companying to learn about this companyveyance, the Official Liquidator moved the High Court of Allahabad for an order that the sale be declared null and void and that Durga Prasad be called upon to surrender the two houses and to retransfer the same to the Bank.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court accepted and directed conveyance to Official Liquidator; confirmed by Division Bench

holdings.text: The High Court had no jurisdiction to grant the certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) of the Constitution without certifying that the appeal involved some substantial question of law and the contention that the appeal is incompetent must succeed; the appeal cannot accordingly be entertained

anchor.surface_text: In our view this contention must succeed. In Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh the Allahabad High Court held. The words the Court immediately below within the meaning of cl.  1  of Art. 133 of the Constitution must be a court other than the High Court. A single judge of a High Court is not a court subordinate to the High Court. An appeal against an order of an appellate Bench of the High Court dismissing an appeal from an order of a single judge of the Court on its original side rejecting a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution lies as a matter of right under Art. 133  1  of the Constitution, if the claim is in respect of property of a value in excess of Rs. 20,000/- and it is not

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Deoki Nandan as limited to writ petitions under Art. 226 where single judge dismissal affirmed by bench allows certificate without substantial question if property value exceeds Rs. 20,000; followed Privy Council in Toolsey Persaud and Calcutta HC in Probhawati Kunwar requiring substantial question for Letters Patent appeals from original jurisdiction single judge; approved concession in Ladli Prasad that original jurisdiction single judge is court immediately below Division Bench

holdings.text: This is not a fit case for granting special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant requested that in any event special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution be granted. But we are of the view, having regard to all the circumstances, that this is not a fit case for granting leave to appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Having regard to all the circumstances of the case

precedents.citation: Shri Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh  1

anchor.surface_text: Shri Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh  1

precedents.case_name: Shri Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: applicants are entitled as of right to a certificate under Article 133(1) of the Constitution without an additional certificate that the case gives rise to a substantial question of law

precedents.citation: Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh

precedents.case_name: Deoki Nandan v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: The words 'the Court immediately below' within the meaning of cl. (1) of Art. 133 of the Constitution must be a court other than the High Court. A single judge of a High Court is not a court subordinate to the High Court. An appeal against an order of an appellate Bench of the High Court dismissing an appeal from an order of a single judge of the Court on its original side rejecting a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution lies as a matter of right under Art. 133(1) of the Constitution, if the claim is in respect of property of a value in excess of Rs. 20,000/- and it is not necessary that the case should give rise to a substantial question of law
precedents.cited_holding: A single judge of a High Court is not a court subordinate to the High Court and appeal from Division Bench lies as of right if value exceeds Rs. 20,000 without substantial question of law

precedents.citation: Toolsey Persaud Bhuckt v. Benayek Misser  1

anchor.surface_text: Toolsey Persaud Bhuckt v. Benayek Misser  1

precedents.case_name: Toolsey Persaud Bhuckt v. Benayek Misser
precedents.cited_proposition: a single judge of a High Court trying an original proceeding was a court immediately below the High Court hearing an appeal under the Letters Patent from his judgment and therefore an appeal under S. 696 of the Code of Civil Procedure could be certified for appeal to the Privy Council only if a substantial question of law was involved
precedents.cited_holding: No question of law arises on the judgment of the High Court, and that there are concurrent findings of the two Courts below on the oral and documentary evidence submitted to them. That being so, the present appeal cannot be entertained

anchor.surface_text: Probhawati Kunwar v. Panmal Lodha  2

precedents.cited_proposition: an appeal to the Privy Council cannot be certified if the High Court confirms the judgment of a single judge trying an original proceeding, unless it involves a substantial question of law

precedents.citation: Ladli Prasad Jaisuul v. The Karnal Distillery Company Ltd.  3

anchor.surface_text: Ladli Prasad Jaisuul v. The Karnal Distillery Company Ltd.  3

precedents.case_name: Ladli Prasad Jaisuul v. The Karnal Distillery Company Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: a single Judge hearing a second appeal under S. 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 is for purposes of Art. 133(1) the Court immediately below a Division Bench of the High Court hearing an appeal against his judgment under the Letters Patent. The expression 'Court immediately below' used in Art. 133(1)(a) does not mean Court subordinate to the High Court
precedents.cited_holding: A Court subordinate to the High Court is a Court subject to the superintendence of the High Court, whereas a Court immediately below is the Court from whose decision the appeal has been filed

anchor.surface_text: The appealis therefore dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed as incompetent for lack of certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) on substantial question of law; special leave under Art. 136 denied
